transcripts.text: Let's go to Russ out of Chicago.  Russ, thank you for calling.  I'll be out of Virginia.  I'm sorry about that, Russ.  Out of Virginia.  Hey, Russ.
Yeah, how you doing, Jesse?  How you doing?
All is well, sir.  How are you?

I'm doing all right.  Hey, I wanted to ask you one of the things that Trump said that he was going to help with the violence in Chicago.  And I wanted to ask you, do you think that he has enough time still in his presidency to make that happen?  Or what are your thoughts on that?

That's a very good question, Russ.  Maybe.  I don't know.  This man has so many issues that he's dealing with, and the resistance from the enemies are just overwhelming.  I hope that he does, but if not, he'll take care of it in the next term around because he will be elected in 2020.
You think he will be reelected?

Yes.  There's no one else anyway, and there's no one like him at this point, especially on the Democratic side.  I heard a report this morning that Joe Biden, something's wrong with that man, Joe Biden may announce that he's going to run, and it's being reported that he may use that woman.  Remember that black woman with the nappa hair out of Georgia that ran, but she lost?  She ran for governor?  Yeah.  Stacey Abrams.
Don't do that.  Don't be like that.
Like what?  By the nappy hair?
You don't have to, like, say nappy hair.  That's not.
But, Russ, Russ, I got it.  Should a woman go out of her house with her head looking like that?
Oh.  An individual can do whatever they want to do.
Should they do it, though?
That's an individual.

In the good old days when black people— Listen, Russ.  In the good old days when black people had respect for themselves and others, would a black woman have been allowed to go out of the house, such as Stacey Abrams is doing, with that nappy hair on her head?  Wouldn't her mother make her straighten her hair or something?  How old are you?  How old are you, Russ?
I'm almost as old as you.
How old are you?  You always say.  How old are you, Russ?
Wait, hold on, Russ.
How old are you?  I'm 54 years old.  So do you remember those good old days?
It doesn't exist.  Right.  That's what you always say.  Right.  So stop talking about the past because it doesn't exist.
But morality and decency...
It does not exist according to you.

Hold on, Rush.  Hold on, buddy.  Morality and decency still exist because God's laws are the same.  Yesterday... Today and forever.  And so black people used to be a decent black people.  They would not allow the women to act and look and be the way that they are.  You know that, and I know that.  And this woman should not be leaving the house with all that nappy out her head.  Definitely.
Don't tell, number one, don't tell me what I know because you don't know what I know.

So you don't know the truth.  You don't know the truth.  Stop.  You don't know the truth.  Stop, stop, stop.  You don't know the truth for that.  I want to put Russ on hold for a minute.  See, black men scream just like the black women.  I'm asking Russ a question and he's starting to carry on.  Calm down, Russ.  I'll let you ask.  I'll ask.  We both will respond and it'll be fine.  It'll be fine.  All right.  So, Russ, I put you on hold.  You're on hold, Russ.  I'm going to bring you back.  I have a question I want you to respond to.  And then I'll allow you to ask a question.  I'll respond.  Hey, Russ.
Yes, sir.
You don't know that black people were a decent people at one point in the history of America.  Hello, Russ.
Yeah, I'm sorry.  Say that again.

You don't know that at one time black people were a decent people and they never would go out of the house with nappy hair and looking and acting the way Stacey Abrams act.  Do you know at one point black people were not like that?
I think that your opinion of...
That's not what I asked you.  I'm not asking you about the nappy hair.  I'm asking, do you know that at one point black Americans were a decent people?
I believe all people were.
I didn't ask you about all people.  Do you know...
That's what I'm telling you.
Do you know at one point that black people were a decent people?
I think all people were decent people.

See, Lord have mercy.  Ask the man, where are you going?  Tell me where you've been.  One more time, and then I'm going to have to let you go because you're refusing to dialogue.  Can I?  I'm going to ask you one more time.  Do you know at one point that black people... Goodbye, Russ.  I'm going to let you go.
Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait.  I just want to answer another question.
I'm not going to answer your question until you answer mine.
No, it's a different question.

I'm not going to answer any questions until you answer my question.  I just told you.  Wait, wait, wait.  I won't answer one question until you answer my question, yes or no.  Did you know that at one point black people used to be a decent people, yes or no?
Okay, black people were decent people, okay, yeah.
You do know that?  Yeah.  Okay.
Okay.  As with everybody else.
Goodbye, Russ.  I didn't ask you about everybody.  I answered the question.  No, you didn't.  I answered your question.  I didn't ask about everybody else.  Black people.  Did you know?
I answered your question.

No, but you messed it up.  Like a woman, a black woman, you messed it up by adding something.  I didn't ask you anything else but that.  Did you know at one point black people were a decent people?  Yes or no?  Yes.
I said yes.  Again, yes.
Thank you.  Now, what's your question for me?
My question for you is, Donald Trump is building a wall.
You support that, correct?  100%.  The wall going up.
Why is it that Americans have to suffer for a wall that somebody else was paying for?

In the same way we have to suffer for y'all to have y'all black babies out of wedlock, for y'all to have free black people, for y'all to be having affirmative action, for y'all to be having, now you want reparations.  We've been taking care of you for 60 and 70 years.  The same reason.  we need to pay and suffer for a wall.  Thank you.
Wait, you're not going to hang up on me.
You're not going to like, because you got the chicken song, so if you're running, you play the chicken song.
He's trying to manipulate me.
What's your last question?
No, I want to respond to what you just said.
Go ahead.  Okay.  You said a lot of stuff real quick.  Right?  The Bible Go To guy wanted me to tell you that the past does not exist today.
I don't care about the Bible.  Go To guy.
He said, yeah, big dummy.  I don't need to talk to the Bible.
No, I want to talk to you.
He said, yeah, big dummy.
I want to talk to Jesse Lee Peterson.
He said, yeah, big dummy.  That is what Jesse's point.  The Bible Go To guy is a white guy.
I know who he is.  I've seen him.  I know who he is.  Oh, okay.  I've seen his picture.  I know who he is.
Oh, okay.  But anyway, go ahead.
So you said a whole bunch of stuff real quick, and we talk about it?
We don't have that much time.
I understand.  What do you want?
Wait, what do you want, man?  What do you want?  What's your question?  What's your comment?  Real fast.
Because you said a whole bunch of stuff real quick.

Russ, your question, what's your comment, Russ?  I'm sorry, white folks.  Black people lost communication skills along with the so-called civil rights movement.  How can I help you, Russ?  What do you want?
You can't help me at all because you're an idiot.
So you don't want anything from this idiot?
You can't help me.
Russ, what are you calling about?
I tried to have a conversation with you.
What's your conversation?
My conversation was about the wall.
What do you want to know about the wall?

My conversation is about the wall and how thousands of Americans had to go without money and stuff like that because of a wall that your president is putting up that somebody else is paying for, and it doesn't make sense.
Who went without money because of a wall?
Federal workers.
What do you mean?  they went without money?  Contractors.  What do you mean?
And all those people, when the government shut down, and it may shut down again because somebody else is paying for a wall.

That doesn't make sense to me.  Oh.  I don't—it was the Democrats' fault that the government shut down.  It wasn't the president's fault.  If they had given— No, it's not—no, no.  They didn't want to give—hold on, man.  They didn't want to give the president the money to put up the wall to protect you.
Why do they have to give money to— to the president when somebody else is paying for it.
The same reason they give black people affirmative action is somebody else paying for it.
That doesn't make sense.  That doesn't even make sense.
I know.  I understand.
If somebody else is paying for the wall, then no one has to give them money for it because someone else is paying for it.
Who is paying for it?
No one.  According to the president... Mexico is paying for it.
They will pay.  They will pay.
They have gone on record to say we're not paying.
I'm sorry.  They will pay.
I'm not going to overtalk you.

They will pay.  I'm not going to overtalk you.  Are you smoking pot?  You smoke pot?  How?  Do you smoke pot?  How?  They will pay.  We give money to Mexico, we can deduct our money from Mexico.  Don't worry about that.  I just want the wall up.  Which would you rather pay for?  To have a wall put up to protect you from the enemies or pay for affirmative action or reparation?  Exactly.  Which one would you prefer?  I just asked you a question.
And I'm going to answer you.
Okay, answer me.  If you give me a chance.  Answer the question.  Answer the question.
If Mexico...

That's not what I asked.  Uh-uh.  Goodbye.  Goodbye, Roy.  Goodbye.  Anyway, I have to tell you, blacks, I mean, whites and others, Hispanics and others who are watching, and decent blacks who are watching, I grew up before the Civil Rights Movement started.  Black people knew how to communicate.  The men and women knew how to communicate.  If you asked them where they were going, they didn't tell you where they had been.  They answered the question.  And they didn't try to deceive you.  Black people at one time was a decent people.  T is out of Alabama.  Hey, T. Hey, T, welcome to the show, sir.
Yeah, good morning, Jesse.
Good morning, T. Can you hear me?  Yes, sir.  All right.
Don't hang up like you did yesterday.

T, if you make comments like that, I'm going to have to let you go.  You were on a bubble phone.  You were on a bubble phone.  You had a lot of noise in the background.  You were on a bubble phone.  You had noise in the background.  We can't have that on the show.  What you want, T?  What you want?
Oh, I'm going to ask you a question, man.
Yes, sir.  Go ahead.
You are the biggest...
What's your question?  You sit here.
My question is, why are you such a big hypocrite?
Because I can't help it.  Okay.  I can't help it.  I love what's right.
You talk about, you know, what other folks do.  Jesse, did Jesus, do you think he had straightening combs in his hair?
No, because he had good hair.
Oh, he did?
Yeah.
How do you know that, Jesse?
Because he didn't have a straightening comb.  And men just straighten their hair anyway.  Yeah, Jesse.  Any other question?  Any other question?
Jesse, once you, you know, you're a sad individual.
Any other question?  You know that?  Any other question?
Another black man.
It's like I'm arguing with a black woman.  The men sound like the women.  Listen closely.
Have a conversation, man.
Okay, let's go for it.
You sound like a little retarded child, okay?
Have a conversation.  You don't sound like the black women, do you?  Yeah, everything sounds like it.
And Joel, man, sit down.  Sit down, be quiet.  You know, sit down, put your little tutu on that you dance in every day.
He doesn't have a ballet school.  Yeah.  So what's your question to you?
Might as well.
What's your question?
But anyway, man, I just want to say this.
What's your question or comment?
Yes.  My question to you, man, is this.  Why do you still hate your mother?  And why do you allocate the abuse of women, Jesse?

What you should do is listen to past tapes and you'll find it out.  You and I have had that discussion over and over again.  And you act like you're mentally ill.  You call me up every day to ask me the same question.
And you know what?  You never answered it, Jesse.
I don't.  Well, I won't answer it today.  Do you have anything else?  I won't answer that.
Well, my question with this, Jesse, I ask you, why do you allocate it's okay for men to beat women?

What are you talking about?  When did I do that?  When did I do that?  So what now?  What's your question?  What's your question?  Did you say be a wife or be this wife?  Be this way, Jesse.  When did I say it was okay for anybody to be... T, T, when did I say it was okay for a woman to be the man?  When did I say that?
Last week, Jesse.
That's a lie.
Go to a columnist.
